messages.text: hey guys, new here, is Julia good for bioinformatics?

text.text: hey guys, new here, is Julia good for bioinformatics?

messages.text: i have no idea what bioinformatics is but julia is pretty versatile, i'm sure you can make it work

text.text: i have no idea what bioinformatics is but julia is pretty versatile, i'm sure you can make it work

messages.text: yeah, super good for bioinformatic - the core of julia is math-oriented design, incredibly high-speed, and easy cross-compilation for different platforms

text.text: yeah, super good for bioinformatic - the core of julia is math-oriented design, incredibly high-speed, and easy cross-compilation for different platforms

messages.text: so to say, it fits lots of the requirements for scientific computing, mainly speed and clarity of meaning (in the code you write)

text.text: so to say, it fits lots of the requirements for scientific computing, mainly speed and clarity of meaning (in the code you write)

messages.text: <https://github.com/BioJulia>

I'm a bioinformatician who uses Julia as a daily driver. Julia is amazing for bioinfo, it's as if it was built for it. I'll be happy to answer any questions.
It's biology ecosystem is pretty incomplete and lacking, though, so you'll have to either be a "do it yourself" person or else you'll have to fall back on Python

elements.text:
I'm a bioinformatician who uses Julia as a daily driver. Julia is amazing for bioinfo, it's as if it was built for it. I'll be happy to answer any questions.
It's biology ecosystem is pretty incomplete and lacking, though, so you'll have to either be a "do it yourself" person or else you'll have to fall back on Python

messages.text: My girlfriend and I ported a Polygenic Risk Score (PRS) algorithm to Julia and gained almost 5-times lower runtime than the original (Python) implementation: <https://github.com/fauconab/PRS.jl>

text.text: My girlfriend and I ported a Polygenic Risk Score (PRS) algorithm to Julia and gained almost 5-times lower runtime than the original (Python) implementation: <https://github.com/fauconab/PRS.jl>

messages.text: It was surprisingly easy to port, and the performance benefits were immediate

text.text: It was surprisingly easy to port, and the performance benefits were immediate

messages.text: We're working on adding GPU support now, and so far it's been pretty painless

text.text: We're working on adding GPU support now, and so far it's been pretty painless

attachments.title: JuliaLang
attachments.text: This is the Zulip server for the Julia programming language community. We ask anyone joining to adhere to the Julia Code of Conduct. | To learn more about Julia, check out <https://julialang.org/>, or just come ask us here! | You can reach out to the admins of this Zulip by sending a direct message to @zulip-admins.

messages.text:

   true
    println("true")
end```
should work fine

messages.text: hey guys, Is julia good for functional programming?

text.text: hey guys, Is julia good for functional programming?

messages.text: Yep
Certainly, you can pass functions around just like other variables and we have closures.

text.text: Certainly, you can pass functions around just like other variables and we have closures.

messages.text: I would say Julia leans more imperative, but there are functional programming features like higher-order functions, anonymous functions, and lambdas.

text.text: I would say Julia leans more imperative, but there are functional programming features like higher-order functions, anonymous functions, and lambdas.

messages.text: If you want to learn functional programming I think there are better options, if you want to use what you have learned from functional programming Julia can accommodate most of it.

text.text: If you want to learn functional programming I think there are better options, if you want to use what you have learned from functional programming Julia can accommodate most of it.

messages.text: I see thanks

messages.text: is LBYL or EAFP more idiomatic in Julia?

messages.text: Hello. Aside from looping, is there some functional approach to sum all like fields of an array of structures? Such as sum every 'r' field of an image?

text.text: Hello. Aside from looping, is there some functional approach to sum all like fields of an array of structures? Such as sum every 'r' field of an image?

messages.text: Sure, ``` sum(x -> x.r, img) ```

text.text:
Sure,
```
sum(x -> x.r, img)
```
